Articles.Content:
Please, for the love of Kerbal. I've been seeing this everywhere since we got other planets with atmospheres.

"Break" or "breaking" is what happens when you screw up.

"Brake" or "braking" is what happens when you get it right.

Do you have "breaks" on your car? I hope not.
If you don't aerobrake, you'll definitely experience a whole lotta aero-breaking.

Worry not about this sort of thing. You'll find a fair few don't have English as a native language, and have trouble with this. The others are just careless. It's annoying, but chances are most won't read this thread. If you see it, just a gentle correction is all that's needed, really.

In KSP, sometime, there is little difference between braking and breaking.

I crashed a few ships in my time. When they break, they stop moving. That's like braking, isn't it? No difference to me. That's why those words sounds the same, I think

I highly disagree with Lesarthois.

When something breaks, it, by definition, loses functionality or becomes useless

When something BRAKES, then it performs an action to slow itself down.
I was not serious
i'm not english, and i must say, this little calembour is particularly fitting with KSP. nice one Zoom
I find I aerobreak a lot. That's what I call it when my rocket falls apart under 20km

The difference between aerobraking and aerobreaking is a couple thousand meters on your periapsis altitude.

Cheers

Once they add re-entry heat we can aerobake

...I'll get my coat

Once they add re-entry heat we can aerobake

...I'll get my coat

Anybody's up to some interplanetary fry-bys?

Anybody's up to some interplanetary fry-bys?

I'll get the marshmallows!

I'll get the marshmallows!

Screw that sh*t, I'm getting popcorn.

Screw all that. I'm strapping some muffin batter to the side of my command pod so my Kerbals can enjoy some delicious muffins upon their successful return to Kerbin for a job well done (and surviving, which is about 90% of the battle).

The difference between aerobraking and aerobreaking is a couple thousand meters on your periapsis altitude.

Cheers

Bahahahahha! That was awesome. Picking myself off the floor after that. Lol!

Once they add re-entry heat we can aerobake

...I'll get my coat

Cricket, cricket, cricket... Is this thing on?

The difference between aerobraking and aerobreaking is a couple thousand meters on your periapsis altitude.

Cheers

Uhh, that's not right. You are referring to the difference between aerobraking and lithobraking!
Aerobreak until you F9 enough to Aerobrake.

I'm convinced that the Internet will lead to changing the official word for 'brake' to 'break', and also that we'll be writing 'there' when we really mean 'their' or 'they're'.

I guess most people never could write, it's just that now everyone can get online, so we can actually see the sorry result!

I'm convinced that the Internet will lead to changing the official word for 'brake' to 'break', and also that we'll be writing 'there' when we really mean 'their' or 'they're'.

I guess most people never could write, it's just that now everyone can get online, so we can actually see the sorry result!

It kinda reminds me of this: http://www.etni.org.il/farside/euroenglish.htm

The difference between aerobraking and aerobreaking is a couple thousand meters on your periapsis altitude.

Cheers

That would be terrabraking, and would be followed by terrabreaking.
I think the correct term is Lithobraking,

I think the correct term is Lithobraking,

SHHHHH!!!!! Your ruining my carefully layed made up words! Nice 3000th post, btw
I frequent car forums and I see "Breaking" everywhere and it's the most annoying thing ever to my inner grammar nazi.

'Litho' means rock/stone. Although it was a coined phrase made up to compliment aerobraking when referring to something using the ground to stop, it is widely regarded as the correct terminology for such a maneuvre.

If you were 'terrabraking', that means you are using the Earth to stop you.

If you were 'terrabraking', that means you are using the Earth to stop you.

Sounds about right.
